title: 1¬† notes
text:
3.1 Skill Categories

Building awareness around the potential negative consequences of encountering high-risk situations and thoughts that associate substance use with good outcomes (i.e., it challenges positive expectancies surrounding substance use
Helping the patient to develop and expand their repertoire of coping skills that address specific high-risk situations for relapse (often called ‚Äútriggers‚Äù), whether those situations lead to drug use-related thoughts, feelings, or bodily sensations

Skills range from techniques to communicate with others when in a risky situation (e.g., how to confidently and comfortably say ‚Äúno‚Äù to a drink if it is offered, called ‚Äúassertive drink and drug refusal‚Äù), to ‚Äúurge surfing,‚Äù a technique to help individuals cope with the intense longings to consume the substance that occurs during cravings

Planning for ‚Äúemergencies.‚Äù That is, unexpected situations where the patient finds themselves suddenly struggling to abstain from drinking or using other drugs
Assessing and reinforcing the patient‚Äôs confidence in his/her ability to abstain from substance use, even in the face of challenging situations (e.g., self-efficacy)
Finding alternative ways of thinking about positive thoughts related to substance use, and negative thoughts related to abstinence, sometimes called ‚Äúcognitive restructuring.‚Äù This activity includes discussing the thinking ‚Äútraps‚Äù (sometimes called cognitive distortions, or unhelpful thinking styles) that can develop after years of drinking and using other drugs. See visuals below for examples of how this work might look

title: 2¬† craving
text:
3 üåä Understanding Cravings
As you work on changing your drinking, it‚Äôs normal to have urges or cravings for alcohol. A craving is when you feel the strong urge to drink, even though you don‚Äôt want to. This can show up as thoughts, emotions, or physical sensations that pull you toward drinking, even if part of you wants to stay sober.
Good news: Cravings are short-lived, predictable, and controllable. With practice, they will get weaker, and you‚Äôll feel more confident in handling them when they pop up.

title: 2¬† craving
text:
3.1 What are cravings?
Broadly, craving refers to a strong desire to use alcohol or other drugs that, if unfulfilled, produces an often powerful degree of physical and/or mental suffering. Cravings are the result of long-term alcohol and/or other drug use and can continue for some time after the use has stopped. People with a history of heavier use might experience stronger or more frequent urges. Experiencing cravings is a normal part of recovery and is common across all stages of recovery.
Cravings and urges can show up in many ways, such as:

Physical sensations (e.g., sweating, heart racing, queasy stomach)
Thoughts (e.g., ‚ÄúA drink sounds good right now‚Äù, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be with my friends getting drunk tonight‚Äù)
Positive expectancies (e.g., ‚ÄúI would have more fun if I was drinking‚Äù)
Emotions (e.g., anxiety, depression, irritability)
Behaviors (e.g., pausing while passing the beer display in a store, hanging out in bars or with others who are drinking).

title: 2¬† craving
text:
3.2 Cravings are PREDICTABLE
Cravings can occur in response to triggers (e.g.¬†being around people or situations that remind someone of past alcohol use) or withdrawal (stopping regular use of alcohol).
Withdrawal: Our brains begin to regulate themselves with alcohol. Without it, the brain makes chemical demands and requests for alcohol. You can expect cravings from withdrawal to be present at the beginning of recovery and diminish over time
Triggers have to do with our memories of alcohol. Alcohol and other drugs flood our brain with reward chemicals like dopamine. Long after our last drink, our brains and memories still associate drinking with this flood of reward. When we‚Äôre exposed to a cue or stimulus that triggers those latent memories, our brains beg us for more reward chemicals. And thus a craving is born.
Cravings can be internal or external:
Internal Situations:

Unpleasant emotions (e.g., frustration, depression, anger, feeling ‚Äústressed out‚Äù)
Pleasant emotions (e.g., joy, excitement)
Physical feelings (e.g., sick, shaky, tense, in pain)
Thoughts about drinking (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôll feel better if I get drink‚Äù)

External Situations

Exposure to alcohol (e.g.¬†alcohol in the home)
Smell, sight and sounds of other people drinking
Particular times during the day when drinking used to occur (e.g., getting off work, weekends, payday)
Stimuli previously associated with drinking (e.g., wine glasses, bar, , ATM machine)
Stimuli previously associated with withdrawal (e.g., hospital, aspirin, morning)

The more we learn to better identify our cravings, the better we can predict them

title: 2¬† craving
text:
3.3 Cravings are TEMPORARY
Though the experience of cravings may be incredibly intense, it is important to remember that cravings are time-limited and WILL PASS. Most cravings last only a few minutes.
A craving is just like a wave at the beach. Every wave in a set starts off small, builds up to its highest point, and then breaks and flows away to shore. Each individual wave never lasts more than a few minutes. A craving is just the same. It starts off small and then builds up. But it peaks, just like a wave, and will eventually break and disappear. This whole process usually doesn‚Äôt last more than minutes. Cravings are time-limited.
Cravings will lose their power if they are not reinforced by using or drinking in response. Even if use occurs only once in a while, it will still keep those cravings alive. Cravings are like stray animals ‚Äì keep feeding them and they will keep coming back. So in a very real sense these cravings are controllable.
Cravings tend to be stronger earlier on, then weaken, and eventually fade over time.
Each time a person does something other than drink and/or use others drugs, the craving loses power.
Stopping alcohol and other drug use completely is the quickest way to get rid of the cravings.

title: 4¬† abstinence_goal
text:
5 Abstinence goal
‚ÄúIs your goal still to remain abstinent in the future?‚Äù
Assumed direction: No or Uncertain
Landing page - Patterns of motivation in AUD treatment, importance of maintaining motivation
From MATRIX
Have you been able to stop using alcohol completely? At about 6 weeks into the recovery process, many people return to alcohol use. Has your addicted brain played with the idea? These are some of the most common arguments against stopping the use of alcohol and answers to the arguments. I came here to stop using speed, not to stop drinking. Part of stopping methamphetamine use is stopping all substance use, including alcohol use. I‚Äôve had drinks and not used, so it doesn‚Äôt make any difference. Drinking over time greatly increases the risk of relapse. A single drink does not necessarily cause relapse any more than a single cigarette causes lung cancer. However, with continued drinking, the risks of relapse greatly increase. Drinking actually helps. When I have a craving, a drink calms me down, and the craving goes away. Alcohol interferes with the brain‚Äôs chemical healing process. Continued alcohol use eventually intensifies cravings, even if one drink seems to reduce cravings. I‚Äôm not an alcoholic, so why do I need to stop drinking? If you‚Äôre not an alcoholic, you should have no problem stopping alcohol use. If you can‚Äôt stop, maybe alcohol is more of a problem than you realize. I‚Äôm never going to use drugs again, but I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll never drink again. Make a 6-month commitment to total abstinence. Give yourself the chance to make a decision about alcohol with a drug-free brain. If you reject alcohol abstinence because ‚Äúforever‚Äù scares you, then you‚Äôre justifying drinking now and risking relapse to substance use.
Motivation for recovery
‚ÄúFear will get people into treatment, but fear alone is not enough to keep them in recovery‚Äù
Ask any group of people who are new to recovery why they want to stop using right now and you will get many different answers: ‚óè I was arrested, and it‚Äôs either this or jail. ‚óè My wife says if I don‚Äôt stop, we are finished. ‚óè Last time I used I thought I was going to die; I know I‚Äôll die if I use again. ‚óè They are going to take the children from us unless we stop. ‚óè I‚Äôve been using for 20 years now; it‚Äôs time to change. Which of the people quoted is most likely to be successful in recovery? It seems logical to think that people who want to stop using for themselves and not because someone else wants them to are more likely to do well in treatment. However, that may not be true. Research shows that the reasons people stop using don‚Äôt predict whether they will be able to lead substance-free lives. What does make a difference is whether they can stay substance free long enough to appreciate the benefits of a different lifestyle. When debts are not overwhelming, relationships are rewarding, work is going well, and health is good, the person in recovery wants to stay abstinent.
Relapse justification
Once a person decides not to use drugs anymore, how does that person end up using again? Do relapses happen completely by accident? Or are there warning signs and ways to avoid relapse? Relapse justification is a process that happens in people‚Äôs minds. A person may have decided to stop using, but the person‚Äôs brain is still healing and still feels the need for the substances. The addicted brain invents excuses that allow the person in recovery to edge close enough to relapse situations that accidents can happen. You may remember a time when you intended to stay drug free but you invented a justification for using, and before you knew it, you had used again. Understanding and anticipating the justifications help you interrupt the process. Use the questions below to help you identify justifications you might be susceptible to. Substance Dependence Is Cured Has your addicted brain ever convinced you that you could use just once or use just a little? For example, have you said any of the following? ‚óè I‚Äôm back in control. I‚Äôll be able to stop when I want to. ‚óè I‚Äôve learned my lesson. I‚Äôll only use small amounts and only once in a while. ‚óè This substance was not my problem‚Äîstimulants were. So I can use this and not relapse. ‚óè Other: ______________________________________________
Testing Yourself It‚Äôs very easy to forget that being smart, not being strong, is the key to staying abstinent. Have you ever wanted to prove you could be stronger than drugs? For example, have you said any of the following? ‚óè I‚Äôm strong enough to be around it now. ‚óè I want to see whether I can say ‚ÄúNo‚Äù to drinking and using. ‚óè I want to see whether I can be around my old friends. ‚óè I want to see how the high feels now that I‚Äôve stopped using. ‚óè Other: ______________________________________________ Celebrating You may be encouraged by other people or your addicted brain to make an exception to your abstinence. Have you ever tried to justify using with the following thoughts? ‚óè I‚Äôm feeling really good. One time won‚Äôt hurt. ‚óè I‚Äôm on vacation. I‚Äôll go back to not using when I get home. ‚óè I‚Äôm doing so well. Things are going great. I owe myself a reward. ‚óè This is such a special event that I want to celebrate. ‚óè Other: ______________________________________________ What might you do when confronted with these excuses to use?

From MATRIX
Stress is a physical and emotional response to difficult or upsetting events, particularly those that continue for a long time. Stress is the experience people have when the demands they make on themselves or those placed on them disrupt their lives. Sometimes we are unaware of this emotional state until the stress produces physical symptoms. Place a checkmark next to any of the following problems you have experienced in the past 30 days: ‚ñ° Sleep problems (for example, difficulty falling asleep, waking up off and on during the night, nightmares, waking up early and being unable to fall back to sleep) ‚ñ° Headaches ‚ñ° Irritability ‚ñ° Stomach problems ‚ñ° Difficulty concentrating ‚ñ° Chronic illness ‚ñ° General dissatisfaction with life ‚ñ° Fatigue ‚ñ° Feeling overwhelmed ‚ñ° Moodiness If you checked two or more of these items, you may need to make some changes in your life to reduce the level of stress. Becoming more aware of stress is the first step to reducing it. You may have been accustomed to turning to substance use in times of stress. Learning new ways to cope with stress is part of the recovery process. Another Relapse Prevention session will address techniques for reducing stress.

title: 3¬† affect_arousal
text:
3.3 How Do Emotions Affect Addiction?
When you feel happy, you are more likely to feel positive and make healthier or more constructive choices; whereas, if you feel negative, you may be more inclined to engage in negative behaviors and make poorer choices. People who experience mental wellness can cope with stress and make better decisions; whereas, mental illness or poor mental health can lead to problems with thinking, mood, and behavior.2
Poor mental health and addiction are mutually reinforcing‚Äîthat is to say, when you feel bad, you may feel more inclined to misuse substances. Research has shown that emotional dysregulation (meaning an inability to control your responses to stimuli) can not only be a risk factor for addiction, alcohol use disorder, and depression, but also cause increased emotional problems. In addition, long-term drug use can impair your ability to deal with intense emotions and cause further emotional dysregulation.3
Research has also shown that alcohol, drugs, and mental health disorders are strongly intertwined. Disorders and behaviors such as depression, aggressiveness, and anger are correlated with a higher likelihood of substance and alcohol misuse.4 A recent study found that alcohol and depression are closely linked, with sadness being a strong predictor of addiction.5

title: 3¬† affect_arousal
section: 3.4 Exploring The Relationship Between Depression and Addiction
text:
3.4 Exploring The Relationship Between Depression and Addiction
Everyone feels blue or down from time to time, but that doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that they have depression. Depression is a serious mental health condition that requires medical care because it can worsen if left untreated.6
Depression occurs when you experience obvious negative changes in mood, thought processes, and motivation that last for at least two weeks and affect your ability to function.7¬†There are different types of depressive disorders, including major depression, postpartum depression, bipolar disorder, and seasonal affective disorder.8
Major depressive disorder¬†is a clinical disorder that involves experiencing symptoms of depressed mood and loss of interest for at least 2 weeks.9¬†The signs and symptoms of depression include:8

Appetite and sleep changes.
Fatigue or low energy.
Feeling chronically sad, empty, or anxious.
Feeling guilty, worthless, or helpless.
Feeling hopeless or pessimistic.
Feelings of restlessness.
Having trouble concentrating or remembering things.
Irritability.
Loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed.
Thoughts of suicide or self-harm.
Unexplained aches and pains.
Depression and substance misuse or alcohol use disorder often co-occur, but the exact biological reasons for this are not entirely clear.10 People make choices for different reasons, so the reasons why one person becomes addicted and another doesn‚Äôt can vary. Regardless, studies confirm the link between substance misuse and depression; furthermore, depressed people may be more inclined to misuse alcohol.10 Depression symptoms may subside when people stop drinking, but finding the motivation to enter treatment can be difficult.11
Different types of depression may lead to an increased risk of substance misuse, although clinical studies have demonstrated mixed results.9 In particular, people with major depression are twice as likely to have a substance use disorder than people without a mood disorder, and people with bipolar disorder are 7 times more likely to suffer from addiction.9 One study of lifetime prevalence rates showed that, among people who were diagnosed with a mood disorder, 32% had a co-occurring substance use disorder (SUD). Among those who had major depression, 16.5% had an alcohol use disorder and 18% had a drug use disorder; out of those who had bipolar disorder, 56% had a lifetime SUD.9
In addition to underlying genetic factors, depression and addiction may be so closely related because many people self-medicate with drugs or alcohol as a way of managing their depressive symptoms.9 However, instead of making things better, it often only exacerbates the issue, and depression and alcohol use can both spiral out of control.9
Someone who experiences depression and addiction displays symptoms of depression as well as addiction, the combination of which is known as a co-occurring disorder. Additionally, people with co-occurring disorders are at higher risk of suicide attempts.11 Luckily, symptoms of depression and symptoms of addiction can both be effectively addressed in rehab.12

title: 3¬† affect_arousal
section: 3.5 Exploring The Relationship Between Addiction & Anger
text:
3.5 Exploring The Relationship Between Addiction & Anger
Anger is a human emotion that can occur in response to discomfort and is seen as a predictor of aggressive behavior. People with high levels of aggression often display more verbal and physical aggression toward other people and may have higher risks of mental illness.13
Different types of anger can affect you in different ways and cause various signs and symptoms. Some clinicians believe that there are 3 main types of anger, including:14

Passive aggression,¬†which means you feel angry but act out your anger in passive ways because you fear confrontation, such as giving people the silent treatment or saying everything is fine when it‚Äôs not.
Open aggression, which stems from a need to feel in control. In this form of anger, you may lash out because of feelings of rage and become physically or verbally violent and aggressive. You might engage in bullying, yelling, blackmailing, or criticizing others.
Assertive¬†anger, which is thought to be the healthiest form of anger. You act maturely and respectfully toward others, talk about your feelings, and listen to others instead of acting out.

Anger and substance misuse are strongly correlated. One study of incarcerated adolescents showed that outwardly expressed anger was significantly related to marijuana and alcohol use.15 Another study showed that 40% of cocaine users suffered from different levels of aggression.13

title: 3¬† affect_arousal
text:
3.1.1 Can You Recognize Your Feelings?
Sometimes people don‚Äôt allow themselves to have certain emotions (for example, you tell yourself, ‚ÄúFeeling angry is not all right‚Äù). Sometimes people aren‚Äôt honest with themselves about their emotions (for example, saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just having a bad day,‚Äù when the truth is they‚Äôre sad). When you mislabel emotions or deny them, you cannot address them and they build up inside you.


3.1.2 Are You Aware of Physical Signs of Certain Feelings?
Maybe you get an upset stomach when you are anxious, bite your fingernails when you are stressed, or shake when you are angry. Think about the emotions that trouble you, and try to identify how they show physically.


3.1.3 How Do You Cope With Your Feelings Now?
How do you respond when you experience negative emotions? How do your feelings affect you and others around you? For instance, do your feelings interfere with your relationships with others? Do people avoid you, try to keep you from getting upset, or try to make you feel better? Focus on one or two emotions you need to cope with better.


3.1.4 How Do You Express Your Emotions?
It is important to find an appropriate way to express emotions. You can express feelings indirectly (to a trusted group, friend, or counselor), or you can express feelings directly to others about whom you have the feelings. You need to learn in which situations it is appropriate to express feelings directly. You also can change your thinking in ways that result in your feeling different. For example, instead of saying, ‚ÄúI am so angry she doesn‚Äôt agree with me, I feel like using,‚Äù you can frame your feelings as, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all right for someone not to agree with me, and using will not make anything better.‚Äù Do not let out-of-control feelings drive you back to using. Learning to cope with emotions means allowing yourself to feel and balancing an honest response with intelligent behavior.

title: 3¬† affect_arousal
text:
3.2 Depression ‚Äì
Although we know drug use and depression are related, it is not always clear how the two interact. Most people in recovery report having problems with depression from time to time. Depression can be a particular problem for people who have been using stimulants. Stimulants make people feel ‚Äúhigh‚Äù by flooding the brain with chemicals called neurotransmitters that regulate feelings of pleasure. During recovery there are periods when the brain doesn‚Äôt supply enough of those neurotransmitters. The undersupply of neurotransmitters causes a temporary feeling of depression. But this is different from being clinically depressed. For some people, depression left untreated can result in relapse. It is important to be aware of signs of depression and be prepared to cope with the feelings. If you feel that you cannot cope with your depression or if your depression lasts for a long time, seek help from a mental health professional. Your counselor or someone else at your treatment program can refer you to someone for help.
These are some symptoms that might indicate depression:

Low energy
Overeating or not eating
Sad thoughts
Losing interest in career or hobbies
Sleeping more than usual
Decreased sex drive ‚ñ° Increased thoughts of drinking
Insomnia
Stopping attendance at 12-Step or mutual-help meetings
Stopping exercise program
Avoiding social activities
Feelings of boredom, irritability, or anger
Crying spells ‚ñ° Suicidal thoughts or actions
Stopping normal activities such as work, cleaning house, buying groceries

Option #2:
Negative and positive emotions have an impact on the way you act and feel, which means that depression and anger can affect the choices you make and your behaviors.
Depression, anger, and addiction are issues that are closely related. According to the National Institute on Drug Abuse, people with substance abuse disorders often have co-occurring mental health issues, and vice versa.1 If you or someone you care about is affected by mental health issues and substance misuse, know that addiction treatment can help you overcome addiction and improve your overall mental health.

title: 13¬† Craving psychoeducation
text:
14 üåä Understanding Cravings
As you work on changing your drinking, it‚Äôs normal to have urges or cravings for alcohol. A craving is when you feel the strong urge to drink, even though you don‚Äôt want to. This can show up as thoughts, emotions, or physical sensations that pull you toward drinking, even if part of you wants to stay sober.
Good news: Cravings are short-lived, predictable, and controllable. With practice, they will get weaker, and you‚Äôll feel more confident in handling them when they pop up.

14.0.1 What is a Craving?
A craving is a powerful feeling that pushes you to drink alcohol, even when you don‚Äôt want to. It can feel like a strong mental or physical need to drink. Cravings happen because of the long-term use of alcohol, and they can last for some time after you stop drinking.
If you‚Äôve had a lot of drinking in the past, cravings may come up more often or feel stronger. But don‚Äôt worry! Cravings are a normal part of recovery, and they happen at all stages of recovery.


14.0.2 How Do Cravings Show Up?
Cravings can look different for everyone. Here are some ways cravings might show up for you:

Physical feelings: You might feel shaky, sweaty, or have a racing heart.
Thoughts: You might think, ‚ÄúI want a drink,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt would be fun to drink with my friends right now.‚Äù
Emotions: Cravings can come with feelings like anxiety, frustration, or sadness.
Behaviors: You might find yourself lingering near places where alcohol is sold, or spending time with others who are drinking.



14.0.3 Cravings Are Predictable
Cravings don‚Äôt happen randomly. They can be triggered by certain situations or emotions. These triggers can be internal (how you‚Äôre feeling) or external (things around you).

Internal triggers: These are feelings or thoughts that can bring on cravings, like stress, sadness, or even excitement. You might also feel physical discomfort, like being tired or in pain.
External triggers: These are things in the environment that remind you of drinking, like seeing alcohol, being around people who drink, or even times of day when you used to drink.

The more you recognize what causes your cravings, the better you can plan for them. Understanding what triggers your cravings can help you avoid or manage them.


14.0.4 Cravings Are Temporary
Cravings might feel intense, but here‚Äôs the important thing to remember: they don‚Äôt last long. Most cravings only last a few minutes. Think of a craving like a wave in the ocean. It starts small, gets bigger, and then crashes and disappears.
Even though cravings can feel overwhelming at first, they are time-limited and will pass. The key is not giving in to the craving. The more you ignore the craving and choose not to drink, the weaker it becomes.


14.0.5 Cravings Get Easier Over Time
At the start of your recovery, cravings may be stronger and more frequent. But over time, they will get weaker and less intense. Each time you resist the urge to drink, the craving loses power.
Stopping alcohol use completely is the fastest way to get rid of cravings. If you don‚Äôt reward craving with alcohol use, it will eventually go away. It‚Äôs like feeding a stray animal. If you stop feeding it, it will stop coming back.


14.0.6 What Can You Do When a Craving Hits?
When you feel a craving, remember: it‚Äôs temporary and you can control how you respond. Here are some ways to deal with cravings:

Pause and Breathe: Take a deep breath. Focus on the present moment.
Distraction: Do something else to take your mind off the craving, like going for a walk, calling a friend, or reading a book.
Urge Surfing: Imagine the craving is like a wave‚Äîlet it build, but know it will crash and pass.
Reach Out: Talk to someone you trust, like a sponsor or a friend. Sometimes, just sharing how you feel can help.




14.0.7 Remember: Cravings Don‚Äôt Last Forever
It‚Äôs completely normal to experience cravings in recovery. But the more you practice coping with them, the easier it will get. Cravings are like visitors‚Äîthey come and go. With time and practice, you will get better at handling them.
By staying sober, even when cravings are strong, you‚Äôll find that the cravings become less powerful and easier to ignore. You‚Äôve got this!

title: 11¬† Craving psychoeducation
text:
12.1 What are cravings?
Broadly, craving refers to a strong desire to use alcohol or other drugs that, if unfulfilled, produces an often powerful degree of physical and/or mental suffering. Cravings are the result of long-term alcohol and/or other drug use and can continue for some time after the use has stopped. People with a history of heavier use might experience stronger or more frequent urges. Experiencing cravings is a normal part of recovery and is common across all stages of recovery.
Cravings and urges can show up in many ways, such as:

Physical sensations (e.g., sweating, heart racing, queasy stomach)
Thoughts (e.g., ‚ÄúA drink sounds good right now‚Äù, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be with my friends getting drunk tonight‚Äù)
Positive expectancies (e.g., ‚ÄúI would have more fun if I was drinking‚Äù)
Emotions (e.g., anxiety, depression, irritability)
Behaviors (e.g., pausing while passing the beer display in a store, hanging out in bars or with others who are drinking).

title: 11¬† Craving psychoeducation
text:
12.2 Cravings are PREDICTABLE
Cravings can occur in response to triggers (e.g.¬†being around people or situations that remind someone of past alcohol use) or withdrawal (stopping regular use of alcohol).
Withdrawal: Our brains begin to regulate themselves with alcohol. Without it, the brain makes chemical demands and requests for alcohol. You can expect cravings from withdrawal to be present at the beginning of recovery and diminish over time
Triggers have to do with our memories of alcohol. Alcohol and other drugs flood our brain with reward chemicals like dopamine. Long after our last drink, our brains and memories still associate drinking with this flood of reward. When we‚Äôre exposed to a cue or stimulus that triggers those latent memories, our brains beg us for more reward chemicals. And thus a craving is born.
Cravings can be internal or external:
Internal Situations:

Unpleasant emotions (e.g., frustration, depression, anger, feeling ‚Äústressed out‚Äù)
Pleasant emotions (e.g., joy, excitement)
Physical feelings (e.g., sick, shaky, tense, in pain)
Thoughts about drinking (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôll feel better if I get drink‚Äù)

External Situations

Exposure to alcohol (e.g.¬†alcohol in the home)
Smell, sight and sounds of other people drinking
Particular times during the day when drinking used to occur (e.g., getting off work, weekends, payday)
Stimuli previously associated with drinking (e.g., wine glasses, bar, , ATM machine)
Stimuli previously associated with withdrawal (e.g., hospital, aspirin, morning)

The more we learn to better identify our cravings, the better we can predict them

title: 11¬† Craving psychoeducation
text:
12.3 Cravings are TEMPORARY
Though the experience of cravings may be incredibly intense, it is important to remember that cravings are time-limited and WILL PASS. Most cravings last only a few minutes.
A craving is just like a wave at the beach. Every wave in a set starts off small, builds up to its highest point, and then breaks and flows away to shore. Each individual wave never lasts more than a few minutes. A craving is just the same. It starts off small and then builds up. But it peaks, just like a wave, and will eventually break and disappear. This whole process usually doesn‚Äôt last more than minutes. Cravings are time-limited.
Cravings will lose their power if they are not reinforced by using or drinking in response. Even if use occurs only once in a while, it will still keep those cravings alive. Cravings are like stray animals ‚Äì keep feeding them and they will keep coming back. So in a very real sense these cravings are controllable.
Cravings tend to be stronger earlier on, then weaken, and eventually fade over time.
Each time a person does something other than drink and/or use others drugs, the craving loses power.
Stopping alcohol and other drug use completely is the quickest way to get rid of the cravings.

title: 17¬† risky_locations_psychoed
text:
18 üìç Spending Time in Risky Locations

18.0.1 Spending Time in Risky Places: What It Means for Recovery
If you‚Äôve recently spent time in a place that felt risky for your recovery‚Äîlike a bar, a party, a certain neighborhood, or even someone‚Äôs house‚Äîyou‚Äôre not alone. Recovery doesn‚Äôt happen in a bubble. Sometimes you end up in places that remind you of drinking or make it harder to stay sober.
The good news is: just because you were in a risky place doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôve failed. What matters most is what you learn from the experience and what you do next.


18.0.2 What Makes a Place Risky?
A risky location is any place that makes it more likely for you to drink or think about drinking. These might include:

Bars or liquor stores
Parties or events where people are drinking
Homes or hangouts where you used to drink
Workplaces or social events that feel stressful
Places tied to strong memories of alcohol use

What‚Äôs risky for one person might not be risky for another. What matters is how you feel when you‚Äôre there.


18.0.3 Why Does It Matter?
Being in risky places can:

Trigger cravings or urges to drink
Bring back old memories or habits
Make you feel out of place or left out
Lower your guard when it comes to saying ‚Äúno‚Äù

Even if you don‚Äôt drink, just being in a risky spot can make staying sober harder. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to check in with yourself after being in one.


18.0.4 Why Do People End Up in Risky Places?
There are lots of reasons why you might go to a risky place:

You didn‚Äôt realize it would feel triggering
You didn‚Äôt want to miss out or disappoint others
You thought you could handle it
You were caught off guard or didn‚Äôt plan ahead
You were feeling lonely, bored, or stressed

Again‚Äîthis happens. The important part is recognizing it and taking steps to protect your recovery going forward.


18.0.5 You Can Learn from the Experience
Spending time in a risky place doesn‚Äôt undo your recovery. It‚Äôs a chance to learn more about your triggers and prepare better for the future.
Ask yourself:

What made this place feel risky for me?
How did I feel while I was there?
What might I do differently next time?

Being honest about your experience helps you grow stronger and stay in control of your recovery.


18.0.6 You‚Äôre Still in Charge
Just because you were in a risky place doesn‚Äôt mean you have to stay there‚Äîor go back. You‚Äôre in control of your choices. You can:

Decide not to return to that place
Make a plan to bring support with you next time
Set boundaries for where you go and for how long
Focus on people and places that support your recovery

Recovery is about making decisions that protect your well-being‚Äîone step, one choice at a time.


18.0.7 Moving Forward from Here
The following tools and exercises can help you:

Reflect on what made the location feel risky
Strengthen your boundaries
Build a plan for how to handle similar situations in the future
Remind yourself why you‚Äôre committed to staying sober

Being in a risky place doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôve failed‚Äîit‚Äôs a sign you‚Äôre learning, growing, and doing the hard work of recovery. You‚Äôve got this.

title: 11¬† past_use_psychoed
text:
12 ‚ö†Ô∏è Alcohol Use During Recovery

12.0.1 Understanding a Slip or Recent Alcohol Use
If you‚Äôve recently had a drink or slipped in your recovery, you might be feeling a mix of emotions‚Äîguilt, frustration, sadness, or even fear. First, take a deep breath.
A slip does not mean you‚Äôve failed. It‚Äôs a sign that recovery is still in progress‚Äîand that‚Äôs okay.


12.0.2 Slips Happen in Recovery
A slip is when someone who is trying to stop drinking has a drink after a period of being sober. It can be one drink, or it can last longer. A slip does not mean you can‚Äôt stay sober‚Äîit means there‚Äôs more to learn about what makes you want to drink and how to handle those moments. Slips are a COMMON, NORMAL part of recovery and can actually serve as powerful learning moments if you explore them without judgment


12.0.3 Why Do Slips Happen?
Slips can happen for many reasons, such as:

Stress: When life feels overwhelming or too hard
Strong cravings: When urges to drink feel too powerful to ignore
Emotions: Feeling lonely, sad, angry, or even too happy
Triggers: Being in a place, around certain people, or in a situation where you used to drink
Low confidence: Thinking ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just one drink, it won‚Äôt matter‚Äù

Knowing what led to the slip can help you avoid it in the future.


12.0.4 What Can You Do After a Slip?
What you do after a slip is what really matters. You don‚Äôt have to wait until next week, next month, or after ‚Äúone last drink‚Äù to get back on track. You can restart right now. Some helpful actions after slips are:

Be honest with yourself ‚Äì Don‚Äôt pretend it didn‚Äôt happen. Admitting it helps you move forward.
Let go of shame ‚Äì You made a mistake, but you‚Äôre not a failure. Everyone makes mistakes.
Figure out what led to the slip ‚Äì Think about the situation, thoughts, or feelings that came before it.
Make a plan for next time ‚Äì Decide what you‚Äôll do differently if a similar situation comes up again.
Reach out ‚Äì Talk to someone who supports your recovery. You don‚Äôt have to go through this alone.



12.0.5 What You Tell Yourself Matters
After a slip, it‚Äôs easy to think:

‚ÄúI blew it.‚Äù
‚ÄúI have to start all over.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôll never be able to stay sober.‚Äù

But these thoughts are not true‚Äîand they‚Äôre not helpful. Instead, try thinking:

‚ÄúI had a setback, but I‚Äôm still moving forward.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can learn from this.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm still in recovery, and I‚Äôm not giving up.‚Äù



12.0.6 A Slip Doesn‚Äôt Erase Your Progress
All the work you‚Äôve done so far still counts. One slip doesn‚Äôt erase your growth, your effort, or your reasons for wanting to stay sober. You‚Äôve already taken steps toward change‚Äîand those steps still matter.
Recovery isn‚Äôt about being perfect. It‚Äôs about getting back up when things get hard. Every time you do that, you build strength.


12.0.7 You Can Start Again‚ÄîRight Now
You don‚Äôt have to wait for a perfect moment. You can restart right now, in this moment. Take a deep breath, and take the next small step.
The tools and exercises that follow are here to help you:

Understand what happened
Reconnect to your recovery goals
Strengthen your plan for staying sober

You‚Äôre not starting over. You‚Äôre continuing your journey‚Äîstronger, wiser, and more prepared than before.

title: 12¬† future efficacy activities
text:
12.0.1 ‚úÖ 1. Self-Compassion Pause
üîç Why? Everyone slips at times‚Äîbeing kind to yourself makes it easier to get back on track.
üß≠ Try This:
üíõ Mistakes don‚Äôt erase progress. You‚Äôre still moving forward.

title: 12¬† future efficacy activities
section: 12.1 üîπ Brief Self-Guided Interventions for Expected Future Stressful Events
text:
12.1 üîπ Brief Self-Guided Interventions for Expected Future Stressful Events

12.1.1 ‚úÖ 1. Pre-Emptive Stress Coping Plan
üîç Why? Stress is inevitable, but having a plan makes it easier to navigate without alcohol.
üß≠ Try This:


Think about an upcoming stressful event you anticipate this week.

Write down or say aloud 2‚Äì3 ways you can handle the stress without alcohol.


‚ÄúI‚Äôll take a break to breathe when I feel overwhelmed.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll call a friend or family member to talk it through.‚Äù




üí° You‚Äôve already got the tools to handle stress‚Äînow, put them into action.


12.1.2 ‚úÖ 2. Stress Reduction Breathing
üîç Why? Deep breathing helps lower stress in the moment and creates space to choose better responses.
üß≠ Try This:


Close your eyes and take a deep breath in for a count of 4.

Hold your breath for a count of 4.

Exhale slowly for a count of 4.

Repeat this 3 times.


üå¨Ô∏è Just a few deep breaths can make a big difference.


12.1.3 ‚úÖ 3. Mindful Moment: Stress Detour
üîç Why? Mindfulness helps break the cycle of stress and reactiveness.
üß≠ Try This:


For the next 60 seconds, fully immerse yourself in what‚Äôs around you.


Feel your feet on the ground.

Listen to the sounds in the room or outside.

Notice how your body feels right now, without judgment.



Afterward, take a moment to ask yourself: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the next step I can take to stay on course today?‚Äù


üå± You can be mindful during stress, not just after it.


12.1.4 ‚úÖ 4. Stress-Free Zone Visualization
üîç Why? Visualization helps you prepare for future stressors by picturing yourself handling them calmly.
üß≠ Try This:


Close your eyes and visualize a peaceful place‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a quiet room, a beautiful outdoor space, or somewhere you feel completely relaxed.

Imagine yourself there, calm and in control, as you navigate the upcoming stressor.

Repeat the phrase: ‚ÄúI can handle whatever comes.‚Äù


üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Mental preparation makes future stressors more manageable.


12.1.5 ‚úÖ 5. ‚ÄúJust For Today‚Äù Focus
üîç Why? Focusing on one day at a time reduces the overwhelm of anticipating future stressors.
üß≠ Try This:


Say or write: ‚ÄúJust for today, I will handle whatever comes without drinking.‚Äù

Remind yourself that you don‚Äôt have to control everything‚Äîjust today.


üìÜ One day at a time. That‚Äôs all you need to focus on right now.

title: 14¬† craving
text:
15 1. Urge Surfing Mini-Practice
Goal: Ride the craving wave without acting on it
How: Sit still and notice the craving like a wave:

Where do you feel it in your body?
What does it feel like (tight, warm, restless)?
Remind yourself: ‚ÄúWaves rise and fall. This will pass.‚Äù


üåä Most cravings peak and fade within minutes if we don‚Äôt fuel them.

2. 5-Senses Grounding
Goal: Distract and anchor yourself in the present
How: Name:

5 things you can see
4 you can feel
3 you can hear
2 you can smell
1 you can taste

üß† Pulls your brain out of craving and into now.
3. Text-a-Friend Prompt
Goal: Interrupt the craving with connection
How: Send one short message to someone in your support network. It can be:

‚ÄúCraving‚Äôs hitting me right now‚Äîjust wanted to say it out loud.‚Äù
‚ÄúHey, can you distract me for a second?‚Äù

üì± Cravings feed on isolation. Connection weakens them.
4. Change the Scene
Goal: Break the craving‚Äôs pattern
How: Stand up and physically change locations. Go outside, into another room, or take a short walk‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre near a trigger (fridge, store, etc.).
üö™Even 60 seconds away from the trigger can help reset your brain.
5. ‚ÄúCraving = a Message‚Äù Reframe
Goal: Understand instead of fear the craving
How: Ask:

What is this craving trying to tell me I need right now?
Am I tired? Lonely? Bored? Needing comfort or relief?

üîç Cravings often cover up unmet needs. Once we know the need, we can meet it in a better way.

6. Delay + Distract Drill
Goal: Create space between the craving and the urge to act
How: Set a timer for just 3 minutes. Do anything else until it goes off (walk, stretch, play a quick game, doodle).
Then reassess: Do I still want it as much as I did before?
‚è± Even a short pause can short-circuit the craving loop.

7. ‚ÄúPlay It Through‚Äù Visualization
Goal: Interrupt ‚Äújust one drink‚Äù thinking
How: Picture it:

What happens if I give in?
How will I feel afterward‚Äî10 minutes later, tomorrow morning?

Now picture the other path:

How will I feel if I ride it out?

üîÆ Cravings focus on short-term pleasure. This helps you see the full picture.

8. Cold Water Reset
Goal: Calm the nervous system and break the craving grip
How: Splash your face with cold water or hold a cold object (ice cube, chilled drink‚Äînon-alcoholic!).
Take 3 deep breaths.
‚ùÑÔ∏è Physical shock = emotional reset.
9. Craving Log Quick Note
Goal: Build insight and break the cycle
How: Jot down:

What triggered this craving?
How intense was it (0‚Äì10)?
What did I do instead of drinking?

Over time, this log shows you patterns and progress.
üìì Writing about it helps shift you from reacting to responding.

10. Recovery Reminder Card
Goal: Anchor in your why during a craving
How: Read or listen to a short note you wrote earlier (or we provide) that reminds you of:

Why you started
What you‚Äôve already survived
What life looks like alcohol-free

üí° In the heat of craving, memory gets foggy. Your card brings clarity back.
OTHER FORMATTING OPTION:::

15.0.1 1. Urge Surfing Mini-Practice

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre having a craving right now‚Äîand that‚Äôs okay. Let‚Äôs take a moment to surf this urge instead of fighting it.
Close your eyes or soften your gaze. Now, notice where you feel the craving in your body. Is it in your chest? Your stomach? Your jaw? Just observe, without judging.
Like a wave, the craving will rise‚Ä¶ peak‚Ä¶ and fade. You don‚Äôt have to do anything‚Äîjust stay with it. You‚Äôre riding it out, not giving in. Keep breathing. You‚Äôre doing great.
This will pass. It always does.‚Äù



15.0.2 2. 5-Senses Grounding

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs bring you back to the here and now. Just follow along with your senses:


Name 5 things you can see.

Now, 4 things you can feel‚Äîlike your clothes, the floor, or your breath.

3 things you can hear, even very faint sounds.

2 things you can smell.

And finally, 1 thing you can taste‚Äîor imagine tasting.


Take a deep breath. You‚Äôre grounded. You‚Äôre in control. The craving doesn‚Äôt run the show‚Äîyou do.‚Äù



15.0.3 3. Text-a-Friend Prompt

‚ÄúCravings love silence. Connection takes away their power.
Open your messages and send a quick text to someone who supports you. It could be as simple as:
‚ÄòHey, craving‚Äôs hitting me. Just needed to say it out loud.‚Äô
Or: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm staying sober today, but it‚Äôs hard right now. Can you check in with me later?‚Äô
You don‚Äôt have to go through this alone. Reaching out is strength‚Äînot weakness.‚Äù



15.0.4 4. Change the Scene

‚ÄúSometimes, the quickest way to shift a craving is to shift your space.
If you can, stand up right now and walk into another room. Step outside. Open a window. Move your body for a minute.
Even a short change of scenery tells your brain: this moment is changing. You‚Äôre taking back control.
Every step you take away from the craving is a step toward your goals.‚Äù



15.0.5 5. Craving = A Message Reframe

‚ÄúWhat if this craving isn‚Äôt a threat‚Äîbut a signal?
Ask yourself gently: What do I really need right now?
Am I tired? Hungry? Lonely? Sad? Just bored?
Your craving might be trying to tell you something‚Äîsomething you can actually take care of without drinking.
Listen to the message‚Ä¶ and take a small step to meet the real need underneath.‚Äù



15.0.6 6. Delay + Distract Drill

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to say ‚Äòno‚Äô forever‚Äîjust for the next few minutes.
Set a mental timer for 3 minutes. While we wait, do anything else: walk around, count your breaths, scroll through photos that make you smile‚Äîanything.
When the time‚Äôs up, ask yourself: Do I still want it as much?
You‚Äôve just proven that you can pause a craving. And if you can pause it‚Ä¶ you can outlast it.‚Äù



15.0.7 7. Play It Through Visualization

‚ÄúCravings love to whisper, ‚ÄòJust one won‚Äôt hurt.‚Äô So let‚Äôs play it through.
Close your eyes for a moment. Imagine giving in. What happens next? How do you feel 10 minutes later? What about tomorrow morning?
Now, picture staying sober instead. Getting through it. Waking up clear-headed. Feeling proud.
One choice leads to regret. The other leads to freedom. You know which path is yours.‚Äù



15.0.8 8. Cold Water Reset

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hit the reset button‚Äîphysically.
Grab something cold. Splash water on your face or hold something chilled. Feel that shock? That‚Äôs your nervous system getting a jolt of calm.
Now take 3 slow, deep breaths.
Sometimes your body just needs a signal that things are okay. This is that signal. You‚Äôve got this.‚Äù



15.0.9 9. Craving Log Quick Note

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs turn this craving into knowledge you can use.
Take a few seconds to note: What triggered this craving? How intense was it, from 0 to 10? What did you do instead of drinking?
Each craving you log helps you see your progress and understand your patterns. This isn‚Äôt just a craving‚Äîit‚Äôs a clue. And you‚Äôre learning how to outsmart it.‚Äù



15.0.10 10. Recovery Reminder Card

‚ÄúTake a deep breath. This is your reminder:
You‚Äôve come so far already. You‚Äôre doing this for a reason‚Äîand that reason still matters, even when it‚Äôs hard.
Picture yourself one week from now, looking back at this moment. What will you be proud of?
You don‚Äôt need to be perfect. You just need to keep going. You‚Äôre strong. You‚Äôre not alone. And you‚Äôre doing something that matters.‚Äù

title: 15¬† future_efficacy_psychoed
text:
16 üí™ Understanding Motivation in Recovery
When you are in recovery, there will be times when you feel less motivated or less confident about staying sober. This can happen for many reasons, and it‚Äôs important to know that it‚Äôs normal to feel this way sometimes.
Low motivation means you might not feel like putting in the effort to stay sober. Low confidence means you might not believe that you have the ability to stay sober, even if you want to.
The good news is that both motivation and confidence to keep abstinent can be worked on and improved during recovery. By practicing some simple strategies, you can boost your confidence in your ability to stay sober and get back on track with your recovery.
1. What is Motivation, Really?

Motivation isn‚Äôt all or nothing ‚Äî it‚Äôs fluid.
It often changes day-to-day or even moment-to-moment.
Feeling unsure or unmotivated doesn‚Äôt mean failure ‚Äî it‚Äôs actually a normal part of the change process.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to be 100% motivated to start moving in the right direction.‚Äù
2. Why Does Motivation Drop?

You might feel burned out, discouraged, or just disconnected from why you started.
Cravings, stress, or life stuff can make alcohol seem like a quick fix again.
Sometimes it‚Äôs hard to imagine life without drinking ‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs been a big part of coping, social life, or routine.
If you don‚Äôt see quick results or progress in your recovery, it can sometimes make you feel like it‚Äôs not working, lowering your motivation
When we are doing well in our recovery, sometimes our mind tries to trick us into thinking that we can handle a drink or two now. This slippery slope is called ‚ÄúAbstinence drift‚Äù

3. What Actually Helps Motivation?
Motivation grows when we:

Understand our own reasons for change (not just what others want for us).
Explore what matters to us ‚Äî like health, family, freedom, or peace of mind.
Feel heard, not judged ‚Äî and have support that fits us, not a one-size-fits-all model.

4. The Change Process Has Stages
You don‚Äôt have to be ‚Äúready to quit forever‚Äù to start growing. Most people move through these stages:

Not yet thinking about change (Precontemplation)
Thinking about it (Contemplation)
Preparing to try (Preparation)
Taking action (Action)
Working to maintain it (Maintenance)

Interventions are meant to meet you where you are ‚Äî not push you where you‚Äôre not ready to go.
5. How to increase motivation and confidence

Set Small, Achievable Goals: Instead of focusing on big, overwhelming goals, set smaller, more manageable goals. For example, focus on staying sober for today, or for the next hour.



Celebrate Your Successes: Each time you meet a small goal, celebrate it! Recognizing your successes, even the small ones, will boost your motivation and remind you that you can do this.



Remind Yourself of Your Reasons: Keep a list of why you want to stay sober. When motivation is low, read through this list to remind yourself why recovery is important to you.



Visualize Your Success: Imagine yourself succeeding in your recovery. Picture yourself feeling strong, confident, and sober. This positive mental image can help build your belief in yourself.



Use Support Networks: Talk to people who support your recovery. Hearing encouraging words from a friend, sponsor, or counselor can help lift your spirits and boost your motivation.



Practice Self-Compassion: If you make a mistake or slip, don‚Äôt be hard on yourself. Be kind and remind yourself that setbacks happen. What matters is getting back on track.

6. Bottom Line

It‚Äôs okay to feel unsure. That‚Äôs a signal to get curious, not give up.
Motivation can be built, just like a muscle.
The goal is progress, not perfection ‚Äî and you don‚Äôt have to do it alone.

title: 16¬† future efficacy activities
text:
17 

17.0.1 ‚úÖ 1. ‚ÄúWhy I‚Äôm Doing This‚Äù List
üîç Why? Reconnecting with your personal reasons for change helps reignite motivation when it feels low.
üß≠ Try This:


Pause for a moment and ask yourself: Why do I want to stay sober this week?

Now write down or say out loud 3 reasons‚Äîbig or small.


‚ÄúTo feel proud of myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I wake up clear-headed.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I deserve better.‚Äù




üìù You just reminded yourself what matters to you‚Äîand that‚Äôs powerful.


17.0.2 ‚úÖ 2. Confidence Scaling + Boost
üîç Why? Even when confidence is low, noticing what‚Äôs working builds a foundation to grow from.
üß≠ Try This:


On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about staying sober this week?

Whatever your number is, ask yourself: Why isn‚Äôt it lower?


Maybe you‚Äôve made it through before, or you reached out for support.



Now ask: What‚Äôs one small thing I could do to move that number up just one point?


üìà Tiny shifts in mindset lead to big changes over time.


17.0.3 ‚úÖ 3. 1-Minute Mental Rehearsal
üîç Why? Imagining success helps the brain practice it‚Äîlike a mental ‚Äúrecovery rehearsal.‚Äù
üß≠ Try This:


Close your eyes and picture one challenging moment you expect this week.

Now imagine yourself getting through it without drinking‚Äîcalm, steady, and proud.

Visualize the moment passing and how you‚Äôll feel afterward.


üéØ You‚Äôre practicing being the version of yourself you want to become.


17.0.4 ‚úÖ 4. Motivational Self-Talk Reframe
üîç Why? The way you talk to yourself affects your motivation‚Äîreframing helps shift doubt into determination.
üß≠ Try This:


Choose one of these empowering phrases‚Äîor make your own:


‚ÄúThis is hard, but I‚Äôve done hard things before.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to believe every thought I think.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm learning‚Äînot failing.‚Äù



Say it to yourself now, or write it on a sticky note or phone reminder.


üó£Ô∏è Talk to yourself like you would talk to a friend who‚Äôs trying something brave.


17.0.5 ‚úÖ 5. Past Success Reflection
üîç Why? Looking back on wins (even small ones) reminds you what you‚Äôre capable of‚Äîand builds belief for the next step.
üß≠ Try This:


Think back to one time you resisted an urge or made a positive choice in your recovery.

Ask: What helped me succeed in that moment?

Then say or write: What does that success say about me?


üèÜ You‚Äôve already done things you once thought were impossible. This is no different.


17.0.6 ‚úÖ 6. Quick Wins List
üîç Why? Motivation grows when you see that you are already taking positive action‚Äîeven if it doesn‚Äôt feel big.
üß≠ Try This:


Write down 3 things you‚Äôve done today that support your recovery.


Drank water instead of alcohol

Opened this app

Took a deep breath before reacting



Read the list out loud and take a moment to feel a sense of progress.


‚úÖ Small wins = real wins.


17.0.7 ‚úÖ 7. Future Gratitude Check-In
üîç Why? Connecting with how your future self will feel helps fuel present-day motivation.
üß≠ Try This:


Imagine it‚Äôs next week, and you stayed sober.

Picture that version of you. How do they feel? What are they proud of? What do they get to enjoy because of your choice today?

Now say or write one sentence: ‚ÄúFuture Me will be grateful because‚Ä¶‚Äù


üîÆ Motivation flows when we connect with where we‚Äôre going‚Äînot just where we‚Äôve been.


17.0.8 ‚úÖ 8. Ask for Support Challenge
üîç Why? Asking for help reinforces your commitment and increases follow-through‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs just a text.
üß≠ Try This:


Send a quick message to someone who supports you. It could be:


‚ÄúJust letting you know I‚Äôm focusing on sobriety this week.‚Äù

‚ÄúCan I check in with you later if things get tough?‚Äù



Don‚Äôt overthink it. One sentence is enough.


ü§ù Accountability builds both confidence and momentum.


17.0.9 ‚úÖ 9. Anchor Phrase Practice
üîç Why? Having a go-to phrase in hard moments keeps you centered and focused.
üß≠ Try This:


Choose one short phrase to repeat when your motivation wobbles:


‚ÄúJust for today.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt drink no matter what.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis craving will pass.‚Äù



Say it out loud now, and again later when you need it.


üîê Anchor phrases work like emotional life vests‚Äîquick, steady reminders of your truth.


17.0.10 ‚úÖ 10. Micro Goal Commitment
üîç Why? Accomplishing small, realistic goals builds self-trust‚Äîand that fuels motivation.
üß≠ Try This:


Think of one tiny goal for today. Something that supports your recovery and feels 100% doable.


‚ÄúDrink a full glass of water after lunch.‚Äù

‚ÄúOpen the app again tonight.‚Äù

‚ÄúWrite down one reason I want to stay sober.‚Äù



Say it out loud or text it to yourself.


üéØ Showing up for even one small promise to yourself builds momentum.

title: 18¬† risky location activities
text:
18.0.1 ‚úÖ 1. Location Reflection
üîç Why? Reflecting on why a location felt risky can help you understand your triggers and prevent future exposure.
üß≠ Try This:


Think about the last time you were in a risky location. Where was it, and what made it feel unsafe for your recovery?

Write down or say aloud 3 reasons why that location feels risky for you.


‚ÄúI associate this place with drinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing around certain people makes me feel pressured.‚Äù




üìù Identifying these factors will help you avoid similar situations in the future.


18.0.2 ‚úÖ 2. Quick Reality Check
üîç Why? Reassessing whether being in a risky location aligns with your goals helps you stay focused on your recovery path.
üß≠ Try This:


Pause for a moment and ask yourself: ‚ÄúDoes being here support my recovery?‚Äù

If the answer is ‚Äúno,‚Äù consider what immediate action you can take to leave the situation, such as:


Excusing yourself and leaving

Asking someone for support (e.g., a friend or sponsor)

Calling a hotline or trusted person for help




üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Taking control of your environment helps you take control of your recovery.


18.0.3 ‚úÖ 3. Boundary-Setting Script
üîç Why? Having clear boundaries protects your sobriety and helps you stay committed to your goals.
üß≠ Try This:


Write or say the following script aloud:
‚ÄúI am committed to my recovery. I don‚Äôt need to be in places that make it harder for me to stay sober.‚Äù

Practice saying it confidently.


‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm in a situation that feels unsafe, I can leave, and that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù




üöß Boundaries are there to protect your well-being, and they‚Äôre an essential part of your recovery.


18.0.4 ‚úÖ 4. Plan for Alternative Activities
üîç Why? Planning ahead for non-risky activities helps you have an immediate solution when you find yourself near a tempting environment.
üß≠ Try This:


Brainstorm 2‚Äì3 activities you can do if you find yourself near a risky place. These could include:


Calling a supportive person

Going to a park or taking a walk

Engaging in a favorite hobby (e.g., reading, journaling, art)



Write these down and keep them handy.


üìÖ Preparation makes it easier to shift gears when you‚Äôre faced with temptation.


18.0.5 ‚úÖ 5. Reaffirm Your Recovery Goals
üîç Why? Reinforcing your long-term recovery goals helps you see past immediate temptation and stay focused on what really matters.
üß≠ Try This:


Write or say aloud: ‚ÄúI am committed to staying sober because [insert personal reasons].‚Äù

Revisit the list of reasons you‚Äôre working toward sobriety‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs to improve your health, relationships, or career.


üéØ By connecting with the bigger picture, you strengthen your resolve.


18.0.6 ‚úÖ 6. Post-Risk Location Check-In
üîç Why? After spending time in a risky location, reflecting on the experience helps you process and learn for the future.
üß≠ Try This:


After leaving a risky place, take a moment to reflect:


How did I feel while I was there?

What did I learn about myself in that situation?

What would I do differently next time?



Write down any insights or action steps.


üîÑ Reflection transforms experiences into learning moments that help you grow stronger in your recovery.


18.0.7 ‚úÖ 7. Urgency Distraction
üîç Why? Creating a distraction when you‚Äôre near a risky location can help you avoid giving in to temptation.
üß≠ Try This:


If you find yourself in a risky location, distract yourself by doing something else, such as:


Listening to a podcast, audiobook, or music

Counting backward from 100

Walking to a different part of the area or stepping outside to get fresh air



This shift in focus can break the cycle of temptation.


üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è A simple change of focus can shift your energy and mind away from the risk.


18.0.8 ‚úÖ 8. Support Check-In
üîç Why? Reaching out to a trusted person increases accountability and provides emotional support in a risky situation.
üß≠ Try This:


Call or text someone you trust‚Äîthis could be a sponsor, friend, or family member‚Äîand let them know where you are.

Say: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in a place that feels risky. Could we talk for a bit?‚Äù


üì± A quick check-in with a support person can provide reassurance and strengthen your resolve.


18.0.9 ‚úÖ 9. ‚ÄúNot Today‚Äù Mindset
üîç Why? Committing to avoid risky situations for today reinforces your sense of control and empowers you to make healthier choices.
üß≠ Try This:


Say aloud: ‚ÄúNot today. I‚Äôm not going to drink or use today, no matter what.‚Äù

Repeat this affirmation a few times to anchor yourself in your decision.


üó£Ô∏è Saying it out loud reinforces your commitment to staying sober, one day at a time.


18.0.10 ‚úÖ 10. Post-Slip Reflection
üîç Why? If you did spend time in a risky location and it led to a slip, reflecting helps you process and strengthen future choices.
üß≠ Try This:


Take a moment to reflect on the situation that led to your slip. What about the location or environment contributed to the slip?

Ask yourself: What can I do differently next time to avoid that situation or respond in a healthier way?

Write down 2‚Äì3 action steps for the future.


üìù Reflection and learning help turn setbacks into opportunities for growth.


18.0.11 ‚úÖ 11. Future Planning: Avoiding Risky Locations
üîç Why? Being proactive about avoiding risky environments in the future empowers you to take control of your recovery.
üß≠ Try This:


Think about upcoming events or places where you might be exposed to risky situations.

Make a plan to either avoid those places or prepare how you‚Äôll handle them if you must go.


Can you bring a supportive friend?

Can you create a quick exit plan?




üîÆ Preparation today leads to success tomorrow.

1.7 EMA item structure
This document will describe (in brief) the relevant support modules that could be recommended for each potentially important risk featured (at times sub-divided by lapse probability). There will be a section for each risk feature. Start with risk features based on the EMA items and we can later add features from GPS as those models are trained. Risk features can be organized as second level headings. Third level headings can be used for sub-categories based on lapse probability. The content in each ‚Äúcell‚Äù can be the name of a module and a link to a qmd in the /modules folder that either further describes the support or eventually contains the actual content that would be presented.

title: 1¬† notes
text:
3.1 Skill Categories

Building awareness around the potential negative consequences of encountering high-risk situations and thoughts that associate substance use with good outcomes (i.e., it challenges positive expectancies surrounding substance use
Helping the patient to develop and expand their repertoire of coping skills that address specific high-risk situations for relapse (often called ‚Äútriggers‚Äù), whether those situations lead to drug use-related thoughts, feelings, or bodily sensations

Skills range from techniques to communicate with others when in a risky situation (e.g., how to confidently and comfortably say ‚Äúno‚Äù to a drink if it is offered, called ‚Äúassertive drink and drug refusal‚Äù), to ‚Äúurge surfing,‚Äù a technique to help individuals cope with the intense longings to consume the substance that occurs during cravings

Planning for ‚Äúemergencies.‚Äù That is, unexpected situations where the patient finds themselves suddenly struggling to abstain from drinking or using other drugs
Assessing and reinforcing the patient‚Äôs confidence in his/her ability to abstain from substance use, even in the face of challenging situations (e.g., self-efficacy)
Finding alternative ways of thinking about positive thoughts related to substance use, and negative thoughts related to abstinence, sometimes called ‚Äúcognitive restructuring.‚Äù This activity includes discussing the thinking ‚Äútraps‚Äù (sometimes called cognitive distortions, or unhelpful thinking styles) that can develop after years of drinking and using other drugs. See visuals below for examples of how this work might look

title: 2¬† craving
text:
3.1 Urge Surfing-
Urge Surfing is a way to deal with alcohol cravings by noticing the feeling, not fighting it, and letting it pass like a wave. Remember that cravings are TEMPORARY. Like ocean waves, you can visualize the rise and fall of your cravings, allowing you to ‚Äúride the wave‚Äù until they go away on their own. Use the instructions below to practice urge surfing the next time you feel a craving:
